item.title: Innovation that Works for Women
item.description: For decades, women have had to navigate systems and products that were not built with them in mind. Now, as research and investment finally begin to catch up, companies and investors need to recognize that meeting women’s needs is the right strategy for the bottom line.

item.title: The Worsening Geopolitics of Water in the Middle East
item.description: Countries across the Middle East are facing acute water shortages, owing to poor resource management, accelerating climate change, and regional power politics. In the absence of concerted diplomacy, water will soon be another flash point in a chronically unstable region.

item.title: How the Green Transition Can Support Africa’s Development
item.description: Despite its vast renewables potential, Africa’s clean-energy transition is being impeded by deepening economic and debt pressures. Any credible climate strategy must combine coordinated debt relief with growth-oriented, low-carbon investment that strengthens resilience and advances long-term national goals.

item.title: Peace as an Economic Strategy
item.description: It is no secret that wars have driven extraordinary innovation, generating everything from the radar to the internet. But far less appreciated is the extent to which peacemaking could bring the same level of resources and collective effort to bear on some of humanity’s greatest challenges.

item.title: Getting the AI Story Right
item.description: As AI moves from experimentation to real-world applications, the limits imposed by the physical world, capital markets, and political systems clearly matter more than its theoretical potential. Fortunately, such constraints are not hurdles to progress, but rather the scaffolding behind which it will take shape.

item.title: Antitrust Delayed Is Antitrust Denied
item.description: Meta’s recent antitrust win in a high-profile case brought by US regulators illustrates the challenges of reactive measures. Taking a preventive approach – namely, challenging mergers when they are first proposed – is a better way to prevent the emergence of monopolies in fast-moving tech markets.

item.title: Daddy Trump
item.description: In the 1970s, citizens of the Soviet Union scoffed at Leonid Brezhnev’s demented vanity, his insatiable need for praise, and the obsequiousness of his entourage. But it was nothing compared to the self-aggrandizing behavior of Donald Trump and the sycophancy of his enablers.

item.title: The Irresistible Temptation of Chile’s Polarized Politics
item.description: Four years ago, Chileans were tempted by the promise of a progressive “refoundation” of the country under Gabriel Boric, a former student leader, and elected him president. Now they have swung in the opposite direction, electing the far-right José Antonio Kast – and are likely to be equally disappointed.

item.title: The Post-Neoliberal Consensus Is Here
item.description: The best that can be said of Trump’s approach to the economy is that it is an experimental phase in the post-neoliberal transition. The good news is that future policymakers will not have to look far for new guiding principles.

item.title: Five Structural Trends Transforming the Global Economy
item.description: Amid rising instability, powerful demographic, technological, and financial forces are steering the global economy toward greater uncertainty. The best-prepared decision-makers will be those who recognize the stakes early and adjust accordingly.

item.title: The Time for Indo-Pacific Unity Has Come
item.description: The Indo-Pacific lacks many of the institutions and alliances that are now teetering elsewhere. But as instability proliferates worldwide, they are urgently needed, and the region's leaders should commit to realizing the late Japanese Prime Minister Abe Shinzō’s vision of an Indo-Pacific that is open, united, stable, and secure.

item.title: Europe Should Stand with Japan on Taiwan
item.description: Just as Russian President Vladimir Putin was clear about his intentions toward Ukraine, Chinese President Xi Jinping has left no doubt about his plans for Taiwan. The only way to deter him from pursuing "reunification" with the island is to make clear that the costs of doing so will be punishing.

item.title: Deporting American Democracy
item.description: The instability caused by the Nazis' mass deportations and Kristallnacht in the autumn of 1938 was unpopular in Germany – much as ICE raids are unpopular in US cities. For the Nazis, the radical next steps were possible only under cover of war – which may be true for US President Donald Trump as well.

item.title: Italy’s Gold Gambit
item.description: By proclaiming that Italy's official gold reserves – the world's third largest – belong to "the Italian people," Giorgia Meloni's government is essentially highlighting its contingency plan for a major crisis. At a time of declining confidence in European institutions, that is the last thing the eurozone needs.

item.title: How to Keep Nigeria’s Schoolchildren Safe
item.description: Too many Nigerian students have had their education interrupted by terrorism and kidnapping for ransom. If parents are to allow their children to return to school in the new year, adequate security infrastructure, clear communication protocols, and effective early-warning systems will be needed.

item.title: Will the Fed Be Allowed to Do Its Job?
item.description: Less than one year into his second term, Donald Trump has already begun to undermine the US Federal Reserve’s independence, introducing risks unseen since the 1970s. For the sake of the global economy, we should all hope that the next chair still has the space – and the resolve – to serve the public interest.

item.title: China and America Must Get Serious About AI Risk
item.description: China and America will continue to compete vigorously for the lead in AI. But as the world’s two – and only – AI superpowers, both countries urgently need to engage one another directly to address the growing list of dangers that the technology poses to markets, infrastructure, social stability, and humanity itself.

item.title: Why China Can’t Win the AI-Led Industrial Revolution
item.description: History has consistently shown that industrial revolutions require free institutions and robust demand to support ongoing entrepreneurship and the commercialization of new, productivity-enhancing products and services. With its system of totalitarian party-state rule, China checks none of these boxes.

item.title: Is Crypto an Opportunity or a Threat?
item.description: Innovation should enhance economic fundamentals, not erode them. With enthusiasm for crypto remaining strong, speculative unbacked tokens and lightly regulated stablecoins must be contained before they threaten financial stability and become part of the shadow banking sector.

item.title: Trump Is Canceling the Rule of Law – and US Democracy
item.description: Not only has the second Trump administration shown an utter contempt for the rule of law, but so too have its allies in Congress and on the Supreme Court. The bedrock principle that has long defined and sustained the American democratic project is being shredded before our eyes.
